com.exacttarget.etpushsdk

Class ETNotifications

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.exacttarget.etpushsdk.ETNotifications

  • public class ETNotifications
extends Object
    A class that holds two interfaces to override the default notification processing. One to override the intent that is launched when a notification is tapped. And one to override the notifications that are displayed when a Push message is received from the SFMC.

    This class provides one of the three ways you can change default intent that is launched when someone taps on a Push Message received by your app. To summarize all three:
    1. Use the this class to override the launch intent using setNotificationLaunchIntent(ETNotificationLaunchIntent)
    2. Specify your own activity to handle the notification tap using ETPush.setNotificationRecipientClass(Class).
    3. Specify an action and URI to launch your own activity when the notification receives a tap using ETPush.setNotificationAction(String) and ETPush.setNotificationActionUri(Uri). NOTE: This method has been deprecated to allow for silent push messaging.


    This class also provides an interface to allow you to change the notifications that are displayed when a Push message is received from the SFMC. You may want to add additional buttons, or possibly treat the message as silent by capturing the payload and letting the SDK not to actually display a notification.

    • Method Detail

      • setNotificationLaunchIntent

        public static void setNotificationLaunchIntent(ETNotificationLaunchIntent inNotificationLaunchIntent)
        Call this method to change the Intent that will be launched when the notification is tapped.

        Most of the time the simplest approach is to call
        1. ETPush.setNotificationRecipientClass(Class) for messages received without a CloudPage or OpenDirect URL
        2. ETPush.setCloudPageRecipient(Class) for messages received with a CloudPage URL
        3. ETPush.setOpenDirectRecipient(Class) for messages received with an OpenDirect URL


        However, if you override this method in your code, we recommend that you call ETNotifications.setupLaunchIntent in your override class to ensure that all default behavior is completed. For example: 
            ETNotifications.setNotificationLaunchIntent(new ETNotificationLaunchIntent() {
       @Override
       public Intent setupLaunchIntent(Context context, Bundle payload) {

          // extract data from payload
          // do other work

          return ETNotifications.setupLaunchIntent(context, payload).setFlags(Intent.FLAG_ACTIVITY_CLEAR_TOP);
       }
    });
        If you don't call ETNotifications.setupLaunchIntent in your interface, then you must include the original payload as extras in the returned intent to ensure the correct processing is completed by the SDK when the message is tapped.

        The parameters in the interface override will be:
        • context: application context
        • payload: the bundle of extras contained in the alert received from the SFMC

        The returned value must be the intent which includes all the data sent from the SFMC so that the SDK can properly handle the notifications when they are tapped.

      • setNotificationBuilder

        public static void setNotificationBuilder(ETNotificationBuilder inNotificationBuilder)
        Call this method to change the notification that is displayed when a Push message is received from the SFMC.

        Return null from your Overridden method to not display any notification for a specific message. This would be a useful feature if you want to notify your app and do internal processing from data sent in the payload, but not actually notify your customers with a notification.

        Example: 
              ETNotifications.setNotificationBuilder(new ETNotificationBuilder() {
          @Override
          public NotificationCompat.Builder setupNotificationBuilder(Context context, Bundle payload) {

              // Allow the SDK to setup the builder
              NotificationCompat.Builder builder = ETNotifications.setupNotificationBuilder(context, payload);

              // Add additional capabilities to the notification such as displaying buttons based on the category sent

              return builder;
          }
      });
        The parameters in the interface override will be:
        • context: application context
        • payload: the bundle of extras contained in the alert received from the SFMC

        The returned value must be a NotificationCompat.Builder

      • createPendingIntentWithOpenAnalytics

        @Deprecated
public static android.app.PendingIntent createPendingIntentWithOpenAnalytics(android.content.Context context,
                                                                        android.content.Intent launchIntent,
                                                                        boolean autoCancel)
        Deprecated. Use one of the other two methods to override notifications that will handle Analytics for you automatically.
        Call this function from your derived class. Useful for ensuring Intents fired from notification action buttons are properly handled by ETAnalytics.
        Parameters:
        context - application context
        launchIntent - launch intent for notification
        autoCancel - should notification auto cancel
        Returns:
        PendingIntent
